title: USS Pigeon (AM-374)
text:
USS "Pigeon" (AM-374) was an acquired by the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> for the dangerous task of removing mines from minefields laid in the water to prevent ships from passing.
"Pigeon" was laid down 10 November 1944 by the <a href="Savannah%20Machine%20and%20Foundry">Savannah Machine and Foundry</a> Co., <a href="Savannah%2C%20Georgia">Savannah, Georgia</a>; launched 28 March 1945; sponsored by Miss Jean Ross; and commissioned at Savannah on 30 October 1945, Lt. Comdr. Robert S. Cathcart in command.
Decommissioned and reactivated.
After fitting out at the <a href="Charleston%20Navy%20Yard">Charleston Navy Yard</a> and operations out of the Naval Mine Warfare School, <a href="Yorktown%2C%20Virginia">Yorktown, Virginia</a>, "Pigeon" was decommissioned on 10 July 1946. Following Communist aggression in <a href="Korea">Korea</a>, she was recommissioned at <a href="Orange%2C%20Texas">Orange, Texas</a>, on 30 November 1950, Lt. Theodore Sawick in command.
North Atlantic operations.
"Pigeon" departed Orange, Texas, on 2 January 1951 to join <a href="Mine%20Squadron">Mine Squadron</a> 8 at <a href="Charleston%2C%20South%20Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>. Tactics and <a href="United%20States%20Fleet%20Forces%20Command">Atlantic Fleet</a> exercises took her to <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, and to <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>, <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a>, and the <a href="Virgin%20Islands">Virgin Islands</a>. On 25 August 1952 she departed Charleston, with <a href="Mine%20Division">Mine Division</a> 82 for the <a href="North%20Atlantic%20Treaty%20Organization">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a> combined fleet exercise <a href="Operation%20Mainbrace">Operation Mainbrace</a>. She arrived at <a href="Rosyth%2C%20Scotland">Rosyth, Scotland</a> on 11 September 1952 and put to sea the 19th to participate in "Mainbrace" minesweeping operations off <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>.
"Pigeon" returned to <a href="Falmouth%2C%20England">Falmouth, England</a> on 27 September 1952 and sailed the 29th with the same amphibious attack force for <a href="NATO">NATO</a> "<a href="Operation%20Longstep">Operation Longstep</a>" in the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>. These and other operations with the powerful <a href="United%20States%20Sixth%20Fleet">U.S. 6th Fleet</a> took her from ports of <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a> to ports in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="France">France</a>, and <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. The minesweeper returned to Charleston, South Carolina, on 7 February 1953.
Overhauled in the <a href="Charleston%20Naval%20Shipyard">Charleston Naval Shipyard</a>, "Pigeon" resumed readiness and training operations along the eastern seaboard as far north as <a href="Quebec%2C%20Canada">Quebec, Canada</a>. She departed Charleston on 6 January 1954 and joined the 6th Fleet at <a href="Lisbon%2C%20Portugal">Lisbon, Portugal</a>, on 19 January 1954. After serving in fleet and <a href="NATO">NATO</a> combined operations throughout the Mediterranean, she returned to Charleston on 29 May 1954.
Decommissioning.
"Pigeon" departed Charleston on 15 November to prepare for inactivation at <a href="Green%20Cove%20Springs%2C%20Florida">Green Cove Springs, Florida</a>. She decommissioned there 14 January 1955 and was placed in reserve. On 7 February 1955, she was reclassified a fleet minesweeper and redesignated MSF-374. She remained in reserve until her name was struck from the <a href="Navy%20List">Navy List</a> on 1 December 1966. She was sold for scrapping.
